  labels = {["static"]}>
Return a number indicating our preference for chosing a type of constraint over another, for the purpose of sorting them.

Immediates are almost always preferrable (when they can be emitted). A higher return value means a stronger preference for one constraint type relative to another. FIXME: We should prefer registers over memory but doing so may lead to unrecoverable register exhaustion later. <a href="https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/issues/20571">https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/issues/20571</a>

<Link id="l06018" /><CodeLine lineNumber="6018"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">///    Register      -&gt; one specific register</span></CodeLine>

<Link id="l06023" /><CodeLine lineNumber="6023"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">///    Other         -&gt; magic values (such as &quot;Flag Output Operands&quot;)</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l06024" /><CodeLine lineNumber="6024"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">///    Unknown       -&gt; something we don&#39;t recognize yet and can&#39;t handle</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l06025" /><CodeLine lineNumber="6025"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// Ideally, we would pick the most specific constraint possible: if we have</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l06026" /><CodeLine lineNumber="6026"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// something that fits into a register, we would pick it.  The problem here</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l06027" /><CodeLine lineNumber="6027"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// is that if we have something that could either be in a register or in</span></CodeLine>

<Link id="l06992" /><CodeLine lineNumber="6992"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Derived from Hacker&#39;s Delight, 2nd Edition, by Hank Warren. Section 10-17.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l06993" /><CodeLine lineNumber="6993"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Fold:</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l06994" /><CodeLine lineNumber="6994"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//   (seteq/ne (srem N, D), 0)</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l06995" /><CodeLine lineNumber="6995"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// To:</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l06996" /><CodeLine lineNumber="6996"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//   (setule/ugt (rotr (add (mul N, P), A), K), Q)</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l06997" /><CodeLine lineNumber="6997"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l06998" /><CodeLine lineNumber="6998"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// - D must be constant, with D = D0 &#42; 2^K where D0 is odd</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l06999" /><CodeLine lineNumber="6999"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// - P is the multiplicative inverse of D0 modulo 2^W</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l07000" /><CodeLine lineNumber="7000"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// - A = bitwiseand(floor((2^(W - 1) - 1) / D0), (-(2^k)))</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l07001" /><CodeLine lineNumber="7001"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// - Q = floor((2 &#42; A) / (2^K))</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l07002" /><CodeLine lineNumber="7002"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// where W is the width of the common type of N and D.</span></CodeLine>

<Link id="l07004" /><CodeLine lineNumber="7004"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// When D is a power of two (and thus D0 is 1), the normal</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l07005" /><CodeLine lineNumber="7005"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// formula for A and Q don&#39;t apply, because the derivation</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l07006" /><CodeLine lineNumber="7006"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// depends on D not dividing 2^(W-1), and thus theorem ZRS</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l07007" /><CodeLine lineNumber="7007"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// does not apply. This specifically fails when N = INT&#95;MIN.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l07008" /><CodeLine lineNumber="7008"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l07009" /><CodeLine lineNumber="7009"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Instead, for power-of-two D, we use:</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l07010" /><CodeLine lineNumber="7010"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// - A = 2^(W-1)</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l07011" /><CodeLine lineNumber="7011"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// |-&gt; Order-preserving map from &#91;-2^(W-1), 2^(W-1) - 1&#93; to &#91;0,2^W - 1&#93;)</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l07012" /><CodeLine lineNumber="7012"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// - Q = 2^(W-K) - 1</span></CodeLine>

<Link id="l07794" /><CodeLine lineNumber="7794"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Optimize unsigned division or remainder by constants for types twice as large</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l07795" /><CodeLine lineNumber="7795"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// as a legal VT.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l07796" /><CodeLine lineNumber="7796"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l07797" /><CodeLine lineNumber="7797"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// If (1 &lt;&lt; (BitWidth / 2)) % Constant == 1, then the remainder</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l07798" /><CodeLine lineNumber="7798"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// can be computed</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l07799" /><CodeLine lineNumber="7799"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// as:</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l07800" /><CodeLine lineNumber="7800"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//   Sum += &#95;&#95;builtin&#95;uadd&#95;overflow(Lo, High, &amp;Sum);</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l07801" /><CodeLine lineNumber="7801"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//   Remainder = Sum % Constant</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l07802" /><CodeLine lineNumber="7802"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// This is based on &quot;Remainder by Summing Digits&quot; from Hacker&#39;s Delight.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l07803" /><CodeLine lineNumber="7803"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l07804" /><CodeLine lineNumber="7804"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// For division, we can compute the remainder using the algorithm described</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l07805" /><CodeLine lineNumber="7805"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// above, subtract it from the dividend to get an exact multiple of Constant.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l07806" /><CodeLine lineNumber="7806"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Then multiply that exact multiply by the multiplicative inverse modulo</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l07807" /><CodeLine lineNumber="7807"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// (1 &lt;&lt; (BitWidth / 2)) to get the quotient.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l07808" /><CodeLine lineNumber="7808"></CodeLine>
<Link id="l07809" /><CodeLine lineNumber="7809"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// If Constant is even, we can shift right the dividend and the divisor by the</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l07810" /><CodeLine lineNumber="7810"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// number of trailing zeros in Constant before applying the remainder algorithm.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l07811" /><CodeLine lineNumber="7811"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// If we&#39;re after the quotient, we can subtract this value from the shifted</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l07812" /><CodeLine lineNumber="7812"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// dividend and multiply by the multiplicative inverse of the shifted divisor.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l07813" /><CodeLine lineNumber="7813"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// If we want the remainder, we shift the value left by the number of trailing</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l07814" /><CodeLine lineNumber="7814"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// zeros and add the bits that were shifted out of the dividend.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l07815" /><CodeLine lineNumber="7815"><span class="doxyHighlightKeywordType">bool</span><span class="doxyHighlight"> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/targetlowering/#abddef937939ecbe4cff930c60b055176">TargetLowering::expandDIVREMByConstant</a>(SDNode &#42;<a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/support/regcomp-c/#a0240ac851181b84ac374872dc5434ee4">N</a>,</span></CodeLine>
